bug.short_desc: Create EJB 3.0 facet definition

long_desc.thetext:
Using the same facet id, create a seperate definition for the "3.0"
would like to do this in seperate plugin...
extension point required would point to seperate install delegate class, for example:
<!--EJB3--> <project-facet-version facet="jst.ejb" version="3.0"> <action type="install"> <delegate class="org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.ejb.project.facet.Ejb3FacetInstallDelegate"/> <config-factory class="org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.internal.ejb.project.operations.EjbFacetInstallDataModelProvider"/> </action> <constraint> <and> <requires facet="jst.java" version="[1.3"/> <conflicts group="modules"/> </and> </constraint> <group-member id="modules"/> </project-facet-version>

First step is to create a simple Java Utility project like structure, do not create a XML deployment descriptor until we work out problems distinguishing the new namespace version.
Validation is one issue: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=167097
Created an attachment (id=55533) patch to disable validator for ejb 3.0 project
Moving to M5

Hi Chuck,
I have tested the build from this location: http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/committers/drops/R2.0/I-I200701110425-200701110425/
Here is my feedback:
1) In the New Ejb Project wizard I can now choose version "3.0" for the EJB Module facet. 2) If I choose version 3.0 the Next button becomes disabled and I cannot go to the "Configure ejb module settings" wizard page. I can only click the Finish button. The ejb project is created successfully. 3) Initially the ejb3 project does not have ejb-jar.xml file. But expanding the META-INF folder and then right-click on the project's node, an ejb-jar.xml is generated. However, the generated xml file contains only the string '<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>'. This is not a valid ejb-jar.xml file an may cause problems when deploying on the application server. 4) Sometimes after self-generating the ejb-jar.xml file, the IDE hangs and utilizes the CPU to 100% for a long time. I attach a full dump stack taken at this time. 5) In the New EAR Application Project wizard I can now choose version "5.0" for the EAR facet. 6) According to the Java EE 5 specification the correct new version for EAR is "5" and not "5.0". 7) If I choose version 5.0 the Next button becomes disabled and I cannot go to the "J2EE Modules to Add to the EAR" wizard page, where I should select ejb3 modules to add to this EAR project. I can only click on the Finish button. The ear project is created successfully. 8) If I go to the "J2EE Module Dependencies" property page of an ear5 project, there is nothing to choose there - even the ejb3 project that I alraedy have in my workspace. Combining to with 7) there is no easy way for the user to add ejb3 modules to his ear5 project.
I would like to refer again bug 157185. There is a patch that provides support for Java EE 5 projects. While we working on the patch we faced the same problems (except hanging the IDE) as described above. The solution for them can be found in the patch. There is comment from David that he does not like the way the solution is provided. But, as far as I can see, you Chuck are going on the same steps as we did. So, I recommend that you take another look at the patch - I am sure there ideas that can help you.
Greetings Kaloyan
Created an attachment (id=56824) full thread dump when IDE hangs with 100% cpu

Thanks Kaloyan,
We are aware of some of these issues, and will be looking into them. The fact that the model(ejb-jar.xml) is generated is wrong, and we will be tracking down where this is being triggered. The existing model classes should not be used for the new facet version, but many existing api's don't consider facet version before proceeding.

The JBoss Team's question, ejb3 specific: Does the jst.ejb 3.0 facet need to be a member of "modules"? Clearly ejb3 is different enough that it doesn't need it's own project, as it's pojo-based.
The wider question (which should, perhaps, be its own bug / discussion?): What is the reason that every member of group "modules" conflicts with group "modules"?
Perhaps I dont understand the depth of the API, but what benefit do you get out of declaring each project can only have one module type? So far, the only benefit I've discovered is that it makes the packaging and publishing of WTP projects very standardized, figuring out the parent / child project relationships, and then packaging accordingly.
Many users will still insist on doing their packaging in a customized way, refusing to use the standard packaging supplied by wtp and jst generic servers. They may use their own ant script or some other mechanism / plugin.
In that case, limiting the number of modules to one per project seems to be highly restrictive with very little benefit.
This becomes even more of a problem when other units of functionality require specific facets (like JSF requiring a project with the web facet, which automatically means an ear, ejb, etc project cannot include the jsf functionality.)
You'll probably all say there's no reason for an EAR or EJB project to include any JSF-related code, anyway, and you'd be right, but many users are resentful of having to split their application into so many units according to webtools' restrictions. They'd rather structure their projects as they see fit, and sometimes this means creating projects with multiple modules types.
So again, what actual benefit is there to restricting on module type?

Created an attachment (id=58292) patch for jst.ejb
Hi Chuck, I agree that after you apply this patch, any problems associated with the new facet should be addressed by new bugs. We should close out this bug.
dropped to build
Verified

bug.short_desc: Internal API violation to EjbFacetProjectCreationDataModelProvider

long_desc.thetext:
I want to have my own project type in Eclipse that will generate a EAR, EJB, EJB Client and Web projects in my workspace. I look into the WTP APIs and data model and find that the data model provider for EJB, EJB client, and Web are all internal classes. Also if I want to add my project to the EAR project, I think I need to use the AddComponentToEnterpriseApplicationDataModelProvider to do it, am I correct? However the AddComponentToEnterpriseApplicationDataModelProvider is also an internal class. Is there any plan to make these data model providers public so that I can use them to generate these projects in my code?
Or are there other public APIs I can use to generate these projects programmatically?
Thanks very much.
Could be a dupe

Please see the comments for 176647 for details on how this problem is being solved. Here is a short synopsis:
As of WTP 1.5, DataModelFactory.createDataModel(Class) can be sent the DataModelProperties class. It will fetch from that the appropriate DataModelProvider and use it. The DataModelProperties class should be public API, and should have all of the necessary Properties exposed for use with the DataModel. (The DataModelProviders would then be non-public, and in WTP 2.0, all of the currently public DataModelProviders are being deprecated.)
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 176647 ***

bug.short_desc: [hotbug] The port's protocolcan't get updated when binding generates the content

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 1.0.102 (org.eclipse.wst.wsdl_1.0.102.v200610132000.jar)
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Open a WSDL file with the following content (Simple Service with a port): <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <wsdl:definitions xmlns:wsdl="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/" xmlns:soap="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/soap/" xmlns:tns="http://www.example.org/NewWSDLFile1/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" name="NewWSDLFile1" targetNamespace="http://www.example.org/NewWSDLFile1/"> <wsdl:service name="NewWSDLFile1"> <wsdl:port name="NewWSDLFile1SOAP"> </wsdl:port> </wsdl:service> </wsdl:definitions>
2. Add a port type 3. add a binding and connect to the port type just created 4. generate binding content with protocol SOAP. 5. Select the port and connect with the binding See the port's protocol is "Empty". It should have been set to <wsdl:port name="NewWSDLFile1SOAP"> <soap:address location="http://www.example.org/" /> </wsdl:port>
In the property page the port's protocol is read only, hence the user even can't change from there.
More information:
We need some mechanism to change the port's protocol via the design view/properties view to an EXISTING port.
Targetting WTP 1.5.4
There needs to be more information added here on why this should be accepted as an adopter hot bug. Is this a regression? Is it blocking adopter progress?

(In reply to comment #3) > There needs to be more information added here on why this should be accepted as > an adopter hot bug. Is this a regression? Is it blocking adopter progress?
Yes. It's blocking us/user from creating a valid WSDL file. Don't know if this is a regression but if the user follow the steps they can't create a valid WSDL file or update the model using the property page.

Created an attachment (id=63660) Patch addresses both issues
Includes a fix to update the Port's protocol based on it's Binding reference's protocol.
Includes a fix to change the protocol of the Port via the properties view through a combobox.

Hi Susanta, I've attached a patch to fix this issue. Please try it out confirm it solves the problem. Once it's confirmed we'll request PMC approval for this fix to go into WTP1.5.4.
Thanks.
Sounds like this is accepted as a hot bug.
I'd like to get feedback on this fix before commiting to this. Sustanta, please respond to indicate if this fix solves the issue.
Recieved confirmation from Susanta this patch fixes the issue.
Tested and fixed.
Reopening bug. The fix has not been checked in yet. Still awaiting PMC approval. Once checked it, the status of the bug will be updated.
On behalf of Craig, requesting PMC approval.
Patch appears to be ok. The protocol needs to be editable so a combo box is needed.
+1 Sounds like an ugly issue, patch looks ok.

+1.
Isn't there a workaround?
The only workaround is to edit the source or remove and add the port both of which aren't acceptable to this adopter.
Patch has been checked in. Version bumped to 1.1.102.qualifier
Tested and confirmed in the latest WTP1.5.4

bug.short_desc: easier refresh of data set binding

long_desc.thetext:
use case:
1) create data set DSet: select column1 from table 2) insert table, select DSet as Data Set in Binding tab 3) put Data into the table's column with row["column1"] 4) update DSet: select column1, column2 from table 5) insert new column into table 6) try to insert Data with row["column2"] - column2 is not defined in binding
Now I have to select table, go to binding, select same DSet again, it asks me, whether I wish to flush bindings and reinitialize from data set. Then I see column2 as new binding. Unfortunatelly all Data's within table are now empty and I must define them again :-(
I'd like to either to see new introduced columns from data set automatically in tables, that references them (so I don't need to flush my bindings) or to define them easier way then via Add data column binding button. I've tried second approach just once and it was very hard to complete, many dialogs appeared and I felt lost.

Leos, I'm not quite understand about you mentions:
After you fluch bindings with the same data set, the previous data columns bound to tabel are emty and you have to defing them again.
Take your user case to look, after you selecting same DSet again, the previous bound column1 still there and can query data out.
Could you describe it more detaily?

Created an attachment (id=64577) step1
simple table having three columns. The first column has computed value (for simplicity I just removed some constant, but in real life we do complex string concatenation)

Created an attachment (id=64579) step2
I realized that I need another column - customer id. So I modified data set

Created an attachment (id=64580) step3
But dataset binding for the table did not contain new entry, so I clicked on select element and selected my data set again. I confirmed designer's question and there are four binding available. Unfortunately the first column's binding was reset to original value, my change is lost.

For this case, I think this you need add the column binding for the new column of data set, for example the customerid. There're 2 terms in the data binding. 1. The data set and data columns. This is the columns you defined in the data set. 2. The column binding. This is the columns (binding) you used in the table. Because the columns(binding) of a table needen't to contain all columns of binded data set, it's not making sense to refresh the table's columns(binding) automatically. Especailly the data set can be binded to multiple items. You need click the add button on the binding page of selected item, then you'll can add new column binding for new dataset columns. I close this as won't fix, feel free to reopen it if you still have other concerns.

Can you please look at this report as BIRT user, not as its developer? If you would use your own product in real life, you would not resolve it as WONTFIX. There is a real life annoying issue and I reported request to simplify common use case.
I described (#c0) current way and explained that it is hard to use. When you rejected my request, you proposed me to do, what I originally described as unintuitive and hard to use.
Ok, I will describe my problem again:
It is common use case to update data set with new column(s). When table is already bound to this data set, there is no easy way how to add this column(s) to table's bindings. Can you propose and implement some easy to use way how to add new columns in data set to the list of bindings?
(please try to add new binding by hand, this flow is not intuitive. if you could simplify it, I would be satisfied)

Thanks for replay I have concerns for following case. A dataset can be referenced by multiple report items, so it's not making sense to assume the data set changes will affect all referenced items. For example, the added columns in data set can only for a table only, but these columns are not making sense for another table. So if we automatically refresh the referenced report items, that can generated lots of wasting bindings. I'm working on a better solution. Any suggestion?
I see. What about another button in table's binding tab? E.g. Add missing bindings - when pressed, it will add bindings for all dataSetRow's items, that are not bound in the table?
Well yes, maybe we can add a button on the binding page to say generate all bindings or missing bindinds.

(In reply to comment #9) > Well yes, maybe we can add a button on the binding page to say generate all > bindings or missing bindinds. >
Is the proposal to generate a binding for all data set columns that has NOT been used in the binding?

(In reply to comment #10) > (In reply to comment #9) > > Well yes, maybe we can add a button on the binding page to say generate all > > bindings or missing bindinds. > > > > Is the proposal to generate a binding for all data set columns that has NOT > been used in the binding? >
Yes it is.
Moving to rc1 for blocking by dependencies of model.

(In reply to comment #12) > Moving to rc1 for blocking by dependencies of model.
Is there a good way for model to tell which data set column is NEW and not used in the table data binding?
In old version , we have the button "Generate all binding" and "Remove unused binding". And DEUtil has these codes about Model.

Add 'Refresh' button in binding page which will sync data binding with bound data set. We just create the new bindings for new or updated columns, will not delete bindings mapped with deleted column, for we don't know the binding is mapped with column or defined in customize expression.

bug.short_desc: failure on create eclipse marker when path contains '!' instead of '/'

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060629-1905
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Each time when build my workspace. It's a complexe workspace. Aspect has build on a project and the aspect are copied on a folder in an another project. In this project, this folder in put in the aspectpath. 2. 3.
More information: failure on create eclipse marker when path contains '!' instead of '/'
AJDT tries to create a marker on a file that does not exist. The path of the file contains a '!' instead of '/'.
My conclusion is that AJDT converted poorly the path of the file containing a '!'. example, the path is L/Config.TeamWork.Editor/components/CU.TeamWork.TeamWork/aspects!fede/teamwork/domain/internal/EntityAJ.class instead of L/Config.TeamWork.Editor/components/CU.TeamWork.TeamWork/aspects/fede/teamwork/domain/internal/EntityAJ.class
L/Config.TeamWork.Editor/components/CU.TeamWork.TeamWork/aspects is a binary directory
The error is in the class file org.eclipse.ajdt.internal.ui.ajde.CompilerTaskListManager, line 251. it's org.aspectj.weaver.ShadowMunger in getBinaryFile method where the path is created. It's a good path if i understand correctly the javadoc. the method private IResource locationToResource(ISourceLocation isl, IProject project) in CompilerTaskListManager The method returns in certain case a bad value. It returns an object IFile that does not exist physically on the hard disc notably when the path contains a '!'
Version: 1.4.1.200609201103 AspectJ version: 1.5.3.200608290814
I couldn't reproduce this. Can you attach a simple project that demonstrates the problem?

bug.short_desc: Low performance off port-queries with Derby database

long_desc.thetext:
When using the Derby database with multiple subsystems probed having a few hundreds of volumes, the performance of some database queries involving host-ports is very low. The CPU will constantly stay at 100% for a long time.
Steps to recreate : 1. Probe a couple of subsystems 2. Navigate to the 'Storage Subsystems' within the 'Disk Manager' 3. Select a subsystem 4. Select a volumes within that subsystem 5. Push 'Assign Host Ports' 6. A dialog will open which should show the 'Availlable ports' and 'Assigned ports' (the CPU goes to 100% right now) 7. Note that the buttons 'Previous' 'Next' 'Finish' will stay grayed out
This will be fixed in R3. I am essentially waiting to see how the TV views-->table xformation works out before I attempt to convert the 15 port queries views to tables
Should be fixed now after the view-->table conversion: someone should check

bug.short_desc: Wrong line number method-execution [Load-Time Weaving]

long_desc.thetext:
Only when fully compiled from source can the line numbers be guaranteed to be correct.
Normally, if you are load time weaving some code build with javac then no information exists in the .class file for the code that is going to be woven that indicates the source line number for the declaration of the method. The line number tables stored for each method provide the line number in the source code for the bytecode that makes up the method. AspectJ does 'as best as it can' with the information available, so if you are load time weaving the messages that come out will use the line number table hence you get the line number of the first instruction in the method - which is usually the line after the declaration.
We cannot just use 'line number - 1' and assume that is the declaration line since it is possible for the code in the method to be on the same line as the declaration:
publicString getField() { return field; } // all on one line
Can I ask how are you building the code that will be load time woven? If you use ajc to build it - then the .class files will include an attribute for each method specifying the actual declaration line in the source code - and that will keep LTW happy and your line numbers will match up. If you are using ajc for compilation of *all* the code (not just the aspects) - then this is a bug. If you are using javac for the code that will be affected by aspects then this is working as designed.
no response.

bug.short_desc: [StatusHandling] Status extension point is not dynamic

long_desc.thetext: The status extension point is not dynamic aware. All workbench extension points must be dynamic aware. This means that when a new bundle is loaded that has a status extension appears it should be acknowledge (if necessary) and when that bundle goes away it is no longer used. I'm not sure the first case is applicable but the second definitely is. If you want help with this let me know - I've done the rest of the workbench dynamic support.

bug.short_desc: T2- "ALF Event Action Map" tab- would like a "Redeploy" feature

long_desc.thetext:
1. Click the "ALF Event Action Map" tab 2. Notice the two buttons, "Deploy" & "UnDeploy"
If the Event Action Map is altered, then a user must click "UnDeploy" and "Deploy" for the changes to be published.
With a "Redeploy" feature, the user would only have to click 1 button to publish the changes.

Tim are we to support re-deploying. The initial verion we had did support deploying with modified changes(something like redeploy).Later on discussion we had avoided this purposefully. We discussed upon this, and agreed that if there is any change in the deployment file(.alf file) the user has to undeploy and redeploy the modified contents.
WE will re-examine this idea when we have a server view

bug.short_desc: DiagramGenerator#findConnectionsToPaint() filters out connections to itself

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 3.2.1
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create a Circuit on a Logic diagram. 2. Put ageoshape inside the circle 3. Create a "Line" connector from the geoshape to itself 4. Right-click on the circuit or its compartment File->Save as Image File... (any format) Problem: look at the image the connection from the geoshape to itself is missing
When selected nodes are being copied to an image, connections from a node to itself will be missing from the image. DiagramGenerator#findConnectionsToPaint() method spefically has a condition to filter connection from a node to itself out. GMF does support such connections, hence the condition above must be removed.
More information:

Created an attachment (id=55266) proposed patch
Removed the mentioned above condition. Tested with logic example and a client application.

Created an attachment (id=55444) patch
Corrected patch
Fix has been committed. Marking as fixed

bug.short_desc: Local History broken for some repository providers

long_desc.thetext: Local History is broken for repository providers that use the history view but don't provide integrated local history.
Fix released to HEAD. The TeamUI method to show the history now takes a page source and this is used by the local history actions.
Verified

bug.short_desc: Remaining memory leak in Windows Agent Controller w/ compatibility layer when executing tests

long_desc.thetext:
Although we found and fixed many of the memory leak problems related to test execution in 4.3, this defect is to track a remaining leak that we did not fix. The leak appears to be related to the use of binary custom commands over the control channel during the execution of the test. The test project I am attaching has a test that (in addition to the normal binary custom command chatter on the control channel) sends 4000 binary custom commands to the workbench, and receives 4000 binary custom commands as responses. I have tried varying both the size of each custom command and also the number of custom commands, and it appears that the leak is in proportion to the latter. (i.e. it doesn't matter if the message itself is 8k or 8 bytes, the size of the leak stays the same. If I increase the number of messages sent, the leak increases roughly proportionally.)
The leak appears to be (very roughly) about 1.7k per pair of binary custom commands, though this is an average, and may not be indicative of the actual cause of the leak. I don't know if it matters whether the messages are sent from the agent or received by the agent.
Please let me know if I can help with your investigation of this defect. Thanks!
Created an attachment (id=55269) A project with a JUnit test that demonstrates the leak
Increasing priority to reflect consuming product's desire for a 4.2.2 fix.

Assigning to Igor and assigning target to 4.2.2 to indicate that is when it is desired.
Igor, Please prioritize this with your 4.2.2 work to see if it can actually be done in that timeframe.
Retarget to 4.4 as this work cannot be done in time for 4.2.2, for which the focus is to get things running on Vista.
Added effort estimate: 4 weeks

Created an attachment (id=64165) patch
Hi Samson, Could you review and commit the patch? It fixes memory leaks in XML parsing utils and removes Util.getCommands() function - it is not currently used but has memory access violation errors.

Patch reviewed and committed to CVS 2007/04/18 13:46 EDT.
Igor, please mark this bug as fixed. Thanks.
Hi Joe, Could you test it with an AC build from 19.04 or later?
Resolved

I finally had a chance to test the latest AC, and the binary custom command related leaks appear to be fixed. This is a big improvement, and will be appreciated by our consuming products since they tend to run very long tests that have a fair amount of binary custom command traffic throughout the run of the test.
Additional testing shows that some per-launch leaks still remain, with the AC growing an average of ~1MB per test execution. I built a stress test plugin in the 4.2 timeframe to test this scenario (for both stability and memory leaks), and it still works well. I will open a new defect for fixing the per-launch leak and attach details on how to easily reproduce. Thanks.

attachment.desc: A project with a JUnit test that demonstrates the leak

bug.short_desc: Timing issue when running the jsps on tomcat in the webservice wizard

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: gilberta@ca.ibm.com
Steps To Reproduce: There are several errors that are being shown during a client scenario that are being emitted from the tomcat server. These errors are:
SEVERE: Error compiling file: /C:/workdata/wtp/1208/workspace/.metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.wst.server.core/tmp0/work/Catalina/localhost/areaClientProject//org/apache/jsp/sampleAreaServiceProxy\Result_jsp.java [javac] Compiling 1 source file
C:\workdata\wtp\1208\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core\tmp0\work\Catalina\localhost\areaClientProject\org\apache\jsp\sampleAreaServiceProxy\Result_jsp.java:91: package org.eclipse.jst.ws.util does not exist String tempResultreturnp3 = org.eclipse.jst.ws.util.JspUtils.markup(String.valueOf(getEndpoint2mtemp)); ^ C:\workdata\wtp\1208\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core\tmp0\work\Catalina\localhost\areaClientProject\org\apache\jsp\sampleAreaServiceProxy\Result_jsp.java:153: package org.eclipse.jst.ws.util does not exist String tempResultreturnp14 = org.eclipse.jst.ws.util.JspUtils.markup(String.valueOf(calculateRectArea13mtemp)); ^ 2 errors
However by the time I run the jsps and test the service there is no problem. I checked the Result.jsp and there is no sign of the errors. So defintitely looks like a timing issue.
Too reproduce run tomcat on ibm 1.5 server using a client scenario that generates and launches the jsps.

Gil, please investigate further in a future release. It looks as though Tomcat hasn't quite finished loading webserviceutils.jar in web-inf/lib at the moment the servlets are compiled, also by Tomcat. Does this problem ever occur when targetting a project that already has webserviceutils.jar in web-inf/lib?

bug.short_desc: [CVSNT] Changing ASCII/Binary fails with CVSNT

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060629-1905
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Select "Change ASCII/Binary" from the Team menu for a file. 2. enter a commit message and click Finished
CVSNT Server replies: "admin -k no longer affects future checkins. Use update -k / commit -f instead." The change does not happen as a result.
More information: This is with CVSNT version 2.5.03.226 on Debian. It would be nice if the command issued to the server could be customized based on the version of the cvs server. Thanks!
This is currently now plan to provide support for forms of CVS. However, we are willing to accept contributions as long as they have no impact on operation against the standard CVS server versions.

bug.short_desc: Should we have an org.eclipse.common package?

long_desc.thetext:
Sometimes common code belongs in the platform, but in other cases we have code that may be shared among / common to multiple projects but that doesn't belong in the platform per se.
We could address this with a common packaging convention: "org.eclipse.common.*" seems to be the obvious choice, assuming that we can come up with some lightweight processes surrounding the handling of that namespace.
My initial thought is that while we would share the *namespace*, we would not want to create a separate project -- the benefit would be to retain our existing governance and development processes/schedules/etc. but have a way to identify code that might not have any semantic affinity for the project that contributed it.
What do others think? Is this a helpful way to identify shared code and facilitate cross project reuse? Can we avoid a "wild west" situation with some simple conventions or claiming procedures?

I'm starting to run into this in the remote development space where I think we have as many as three potential solutions involving three different projects. I would actually like to see a commons project whose mandidate it is to bring projects together on common topics and help facilitate common solutions. My hopes were for Orbit to do that but that isn't what Orbit is really set up to do.

I think this is a great idea. Just the other day I was thinking that the XML Schema component in WTP could use a hierarchy view a la JDT. Maybe some common code to do this already exists but if it does not, then a component in a "Commons" project could be a good place for it. I'm sure other projects like the CDT and other languages and technologies with type hierarchies could use a common starting point for this. I would also like to see more goodies from the JDT refactored into a common component (think type selection dialog, search for references/declaration, indexing framework, etc).

There are a couple of problems with having a single "commons" project:
1. The governance. With a very diverse group of people from unrelated projects contributing to such a project, how would we decide who gets to be on the PMC and resolve other governance issues?
2. Eventually this project would need to have a dependency on everything else in the Eclipse eco-system, thus creating problems for consuming projects (unnecessary dependencies and circles).
It seems that you would have to treat the commons project differently than other projects. We could set it up so that it is composed of multiple "micro-projects" with their own governance, dependencies, distributions, versioning, shipping schedule, etc. The top-level PMC would then be mostly involved in authorizing new micro-projects, resolving namespace issues, and other inter-projects conflicts.
It would probably take quite a while to set up such a special kind of a project, but perhaps we can make a start in that direction by housing the micro-projects within the existing Eclipse projects and using the org.eclipse.common namespace.

Instead of making it a top level project, why not make it project in Technology?
Apparently, having a light process for org.eclipse.commons seems to be a good idea. But bringing a plug-in into the Eclipse Commons makes a statement - the statement that a particular component is no longer part of the original project but now available for "common" adoption within the Eclipse community.
Although the contributers and committers still come from the original project, the component cannot be any longer part of it. For example, it can no longer be maintained under the same release cycle. Why? The idea of making something "common" is that it will be shared between multiple clients. But the clients may have different expectations about the schedule, the road map, etc. Thus, we need a group that manages those "conflicts".
But instead of introducing yet another process, why not leverage the process that is already in place? If we make Eclipse Commons a project under the Technology PMC we have a very light process for the actual components. Components can be released independent of each other. The project management group would be responsible for coordinating the development & scheduling for the components. The Eclipse Commons project would have its own update site, downloads, Bugzilla components, mailing lists, etc. I think that's all we need and it's all in place. It also gives the project the openness for other contributors to join.
Someone just have to submit the project proposal. :)

Isn't the Technology project an incubator for other projects and for new projects not ready to strike out on their own quite yet. That doesn't seem like a good fit for this. But I do agree that the way the Technology project is setup for lightweight management of manu sub-projects is a good model for the Commons project, if we want to go that route.

I agree with Tim's contention that there should not be a separate project for this. The only control that should be needed is very lightweight process oversight from the architecture council on what gets added to the commons namespace (e.g., Apache style voting). In a perfect world, the architecture council would be proactively seeking out code that should be teased into the commons, and not just acting as a gatekeeper.

(In reply to comment #6) > I agree with Tim's contention that there should not be a separate project for > this. The only control that should be needed is very lightweight process > oversight from the architecture council on what gets added to the commons > namespace (e.g., Apache style voting). In a perfect world, the architecture > council would be proactively seeking out code that should be teased into the > commons, and not just acting as a gatekeeper.
Very good point, Rich.
How could we get this funded? I imagine that the big companies that have lots of cross-project dependencies (ie: BEA, IBM, Borland, etc. in the Java space and the CDT folks) would feel the pain we're discussing the most.
But do they feel it enough to pay some of their folks to help get this done? (An honest, not a rhetorical question)

In terms of governance model, although I agree that lightweight is very good, I'm not sure the Technology project is the right model. Maybe Callisto/Europa is more along the lines of the right governance model for starters.
In order for the big projects to all be able to depend on this stuff, it needs to have a stable, predictable release cycle.

(In reply to comment #6) > I agree with Tim's contention that there should not be a separate project for > this. The only control that should be needed is very lightweight process > oversight from the architecture council on what gets added to the commons > namespace (e.g., Apache style voting). In a perfect world, the architecture > council would be proactively seeking out code that should be teased into the > commons, and not just acting as a gatekeeper.
Unfortunately the world is not perfect and, with apologies to the members of the Architecture Council, I don't think they are set up to manage something like this.
My fear is that without someone driving it, like a project lead and a committer community, it just won't happen. It hasn't to this point. And this problem has been around a long time.

(In reply to comment #9) > My fear is that without someone driving it, like a project lead and a committer > community, it just won't happen. It hasn't to this point. And this problem has > been around a long time.
I agree. Two more thoughts:
1) Is there an incremental way to get from where we are closer to the overall goal?
2) This is why I brought up funding / committers in comment #7. If there's funding we can go anywhere if we can find an incremental way to get there. If not, IMO, we're dead in the water.

There is definitely an incremental way of doing this. Suppose the ultimate goal is a Technology Project style Commons project with many sub-projects and light top-level governance. The first step might be to form a group that would eventually become the Commons PMC from members of projects initially contributing code, but to leave the code in those projects (in the org.eclipse.common namespace) like Tim outlined. This way the packaging is made uniform and is more palatable for consumption by other projects. You also start working out the governance issues because you have to make namespace decisons. The next step would be to officialy create the project and to move the code into that project (no package name changes should be necessary at this stage). From a consumer's perspective, all that happened in the second stage is that the location they get the plugins from has been changed.

(In reply to comment #11) > [...] The first step might be to form a group that would > eventually become the Commons PMC from members of projects initially > contributing code, but to leave the code in those projects (in the > org.eclipse.common namespace) like Tim outlined.
AFAIK there are no PMCs for projects. There is only a PMC for top-level projects. Projects just have one (or more) project lead(s) and contributors and committers. That's why I think this process is lightweight enough to host such an initiative.
I'm not sure about the namespaces but I think they are associated to a project. We shouldn't start spreading org.eclipse.common all over the existing Eclipse projects. But by saying this I'm talking about releasing code in a commons package as API.
However, it is possible to start right in your project: - Identify a component you want to share. - Find a second API client - Refactor the code into the common namespace - Submit a project proposal with your code as initial code contribution
I don't think that this is too much work. In fact, all of the items can be driven by projects and their needs. There is no architecture council required although I like the idea that someone actively identifies potential new commons components and pay attention to the dependency tree of the commons components.
So why do I think Technology would be a good starter? Because I think it's too much overhead of talking and forming yet another top level project just for the sake of releasing one or two commons components. Let's start small and see how this evolves. Once we have a broad adoption and contributing community and the number of components is growing we can start talking about creating a top-level project.
And BTW, I like the voting idea. Actually, once a commons project was started we will have a committer community. Our process requires that new committers will be voted in. This way we kill 2 birds with one stone.
The commons project would have an incubation component for itself. New component efforts would start in this incubation component. So there will be a voting for new incubation committers. Later on, there will be a second voting for moving a component out of incubation into the commons package. That's how it works in Equinox. Very flexible, very light and ... it just works.
Additionally, the role of the project lead should not be overvalued in terms of commons namespace authority. I would like to have the project lead concentrating on establishing a release process, managing dependencies and thinks like that. But I don't see him as the decision maker of what component gets accepted and what not. That's a think the community (of committers) will decide.

Why not expand Orbit charter to include distribution of common plugins...in addition to it's current distribution of third party libraries-as-plugins?
> (In reply to comment #11) <stuff deleted> > Additionally, the role of the project lead should not be overvalued in terms of > commons namespace authority. I would like to have the project lead > concentrating on establishing a release process, managing dependencies and > thinks like that. But I don't see him as the decision maker of what component > gets accepted and what not. That's a think the community (of committers) will > decide. >
I think the problem here would be getting participation of the (whole) community in decision making for component acceptance. The only way to do that now is to have whole community votes, and involving the whole committer community (or whole eclipse community) in votes isn't easy-to-do/lightweight at the moment. That, and I'm not sure that 'one-committer-one-vote' really works well for stuff like this, as people will obviously differ in their level of experience with a proposed commonos component, level of need for that component, level of corp support for component creation, etc.
I agree with Gunnar though that it can't be through existing project leadership benevolent dictatorship...but I don't know what else we could use.

Here's my take on this thread:
Talk of new processes, new governance, new projects, or new work seems out of place in this bugzilla. As I understand it, this bugzilla is simply to authorize a modification to the naming conventions http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Naming_Conventions so that org.eclipse.common.<component> can be used by any Eclipse Project. And, the only new thing, is who "governs" the <component> names. You could pretty much do this on a "first come first served" registration basis.
As I see it, it would still be up to each project, under the guidance of their PMC, to authorize their committers to use this package name, and in my humble opinion, should be fairly rare that a PMC would authorize such a thing.
Here's a few other guidelines, that I'd see would need to be formalized.
1. The principle by which this is appropriate would have to be spelled out. Something like "used by 3 or more Eclipse Projects, can be self contained in its own plugin (named "org.eclipse.common.<component>")
2. Anything so provided should be strictly, official API, and, I'd recommend, get even more scrutiny that most.
3. This type of "common" component is nothing new, that is, no new work, nothing the project is not already producing, nothing that is out of scope of the project, so there's no "funding" involved ... it is just a better naming scheme.
4. Most projects would continue to package this commons plugin right along with all their other plugins and features, just as if it was named anything else, but having the "common" name better signifies that adopters could "mix and match" their own pre-reqs and distributions with these plugins, and the advantage is that it is simply more meaningful and that there would be more assurance it would always be continued to be named that, even if later moved to another project, or even if there is eventually some "commons" project that manages and builds these common components ... but, that'd be a new bugzilla :)
So, I'm not sure, is there interest by those following this bug that this sort of "new and improved naming" is a worthwhile goal? If so, I all for it and I think the details for that could be worked out. This would be small, incremental improvement, IMHO, but I think trying to "jump" to some common project or some new work effort will never happen (probably for good reason :)
As an antidote, to illustrate my motivations, years ago I sat in several meetings saying I didn't want to use some code that was in o.e.emf.common package/plugin because then it would "appear" we depended on EMF, even though the code in that plugin had nothing to do with EMF (at that time, at least ... looks like it's been expanded since).
So, that's my interpretations of this bugzilla, and suggest we push forward on that front ... and then maybe after another few years of requests for a true "common" project, we'll have a better idea of what that would contain.

(In reply to comment #14) > Talk of new processes, new governance, new projects, or new work seems out of > place in this bugzilla.
I appreciate the effort to focus the discussion, but unfortunately having the namespace is useless without an understanding of how contributions are accepted, scoped, and maintained, and by whom. Those issues are exactly the barriers to reuse that have prevented similar from being realized in the past.
> 3. This type of "common" component is nothing new, that is, no new work, > nothing the project is not already producing, nothing that is out of scope of > the project, so there's no "funding" involved ... it is just a better naming > scheme.
On the surface that's true, but in practice the cost of maintenance goes up as you add more dependents, which in this case is actually the goal. You'll start with something that suited your project's needs, drop it in commons, then start to receive requests for changes and enhancements. You must weigh them off when they differ. Those discussions take time even if you change nothing. But changes will be needed as new usage cases come forth. If you don't do that, then reusability is limited to your existing usage unless your lucky or brilliant. So the cost of ensuring something is reusable is non-trivial.
I think the general sense of the comments, which I agree with, is that we're unlikely to design this correctly from the start. What I would like to see is an incremental approach, where two or three projects get together to identify duplicate technology or other opportunities for cross use, pull them out as a separate plugin, and each project ship a major version that way. Only upon success could we claim to scale it larger, we'd learn by doing, etc. By reducing the scope to start, one can I think avoid some of the trickier governance issues since its really just a private contract for sharing between those projects. If there was real commitment to do this then we could I'm sure figure out name spacing to avoid a future rename if successful.

java.lang.ClassCastException at org.aspectj.ajdt.internal.compiler.lookup.EclipseResolvedMember.getParameterNames(EclipseResolvedMember.java:98) at org.aspectj.weaver.ResolvedMemberImpl.parameterizedWith(ResolvedMemberImpl.java:660) at org.aspectj.weaver.ResolvedMemberImpl.parameterizedWith(ResolvedMemberImpl.java:597) at org.aspectj.weaver.ReferenceType.getDeclaredFields(ReferenceType.java:381) at org.aspectj.weaver.ResolvedType$2.get( ... s when weaving when batch building BuildConfig[D:\leica\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.ajdt.core\brunswick-core.generated.lst] #Files=731

bug.short_desc: 500 error appears when running the wse on jdk 1.42

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: wtp-sdk-M-1.5.3-200612071249.zip
Steps To Reproduce: Run wtp using jdk 1.42. Try launching the WSE from the menubar and the window shows up with a 500 error. This does not happen in 1.5

Gil, back to you for further investigation for 1.5.3. This does not sound like something we've encountered on 1.5.2 or earlier on either the Sun or IBM 1.4.2 JDK. Have you tried both JDKs in this case?

Created an attachment (id=56679) Eclipse Tomcat log
The cause of the explosion is an UnsupportedClassVersionError raised when Tomcat tries to load any of the WSE JSP/servlet classes, starting with wsexplorer.jsp. From Tomcat's catalina log file (attached)
java.lang.UnsupportedClassVersionError: wsexplorer_jsp (Unsupported major.minor version 49.0)
The version 49.0 indicates the class file was compiled by a 1.5 compiler. Since wsexplorer.war is built from its JSPs by the "JspC" and "javac" targets in org.eclipse.wst.ws.explorer/build-war.xml, we need to first understand the build environment for the WTP 1.5.x SDK images (which I suspect David Williams can help with), and then determine whether specifying the equivalent of the -target, -source, -bootclasspath and -extdirs options to force javac to cross-compile to 1.4.

David, can you shed a bit of WTP build light on the musings so far in my previous comment 2? I have a vague memory of the build environment and java compiler level changing between 1.5.2 and 1.5.3. Also, WTP 1.5.x continues to support JRE 1.4.2, true?

Yes, there has been build changes, so most of it is now "controlled" by a 1.5 VM.
The PDE part of the build is still smart enough to use or produce Java 1.4 byte codes, where appropriate, but I suspect this problem is due to your fancy little custom build-war.xml scripts :) Right?
I suspect it currently simply "uses what's running". I suspect we should hard code it to use 1.4 always. You'd want this as 1.4 even in WTP 2.0, right? So it can run on a 1.4 target?

Created an attachment (id=56681) changes to force 1.4 to be used during ant jsp build
If this looks/sounds right to you, this patch should fix. If you can review, great, if not we can just give it a whirl, if you know how to test well.

David, giving it a whirl sounds good to me. We can't exactly make the WSE any worse. The patch looks fine bearing in mind I don't understand the semantics of the value of javac's "executable" parameter, "env.JAVA_4_HOME/bin/java". Also, I don't understand what the "jvm" argument on the JspC task is doing. According to the JspC javadoc [1], there is no such property. Where did you learn about it, and what does it do? Depending on your answer, I'll commit/release your patch with or without the change to the JspC task and try the WSE in the next build.
Thanks very much for your help with this!
[1] http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-5.5-doc/jasper/docs/api/index.html

The jvm attribute is for the java task ... it just specifies the vm to execute for 'java' (for that one task) instead of the currently running one.
Similar for the "executable" attribute, which, actually should be env.JAVA_4_HOME/bin/javac not just env.JAVA_4_HOME/bin/java
the "env.JAVA_4_HOME" is the part specific to our build environment. We always set both a JAVA_4_HOME and a JAVA_5_HOME, each is just like an ordinary JAVA_HOME, except it allows us to "switch" to which ever we need.

Re. the "jvm" property, understood. I've updated the javac target to read: <javac destdir="${wsexplorerDir}/WEB-INF/classes" includeAntRuntime="false" failonerror="false" executable="env.JAVA_4_HOME/bin/javac" fork="true">
I've just committed and released to 1.5.3 (tag v200701101856) and HEAD (tag v200701101916).
Gil, please retry on the next available continuous or integration build that includes this change, and verify/close or resubmit this bug depending on whether the problem goes away or not.

Looks like things actually did get worse. In M-1.5.3-200701102323, the WSE does not load on either JRE. The server produces a 404. The reason is that none of the JSP servlet class files are in wsexplorer.war - web-inf/classes is effectively empty.
David, it seems likely that the JspC or javac targets failed. Is there a log file from the build somewhere we can look at for a clue as to what happened?

Yes (not easy to find), and says this:
/shared/webtools/build-wtp-R2.0-I/workdir/plugins/org.eclipse.wst.ws.explorer/build-war.xml:13: java.io.IOException: env.JAVA_4_HOME/bin/java^@: not found
So, sorry, bad patch. I should have used ant-variable syntax, namely ${env.JAVA_4_HOME}/bin/java and ${env.JAVA_4_HOME}/bin/javac
I suspect that funny ^@ is a windows/linux EOL thing, so this file should probably be treated with File, convert eol, unix before being committed to cvs. though, I don't think related to this overall failure.
Can you re-commit fixed script? Or let me know if I should.
Long term, we should explore getting some better script, that would report failure, or something, a bit better.

Thanks much David. I've committed and released the changes to R1_5_maintenance (tag v200701112118) and HEAD (tag v200701112120). The ${} thing sounds right on the money, but will keep my fingers cross anyways.
I too would like to find a way to get failures to bubble up from build-war.xml and show up under "compile logs & test results" (eg.[1]), but don't have a clue where to begin. In the interim, could all logs under the likes of /shared/webtools/build-wtp-R2.0-I/workdir/plugins... be easily copied/linked/etc. off the "compile logs & test results" page in some way?
[1] http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/committers/drops/R1.5/M-1.5.3-200701102323/testResults.php
Released into the next build.

The WSE in WTP 1.5.3 is OK, however, in WTP 2.0 the same HTTP 500 condition is occuring as noted in comment 9. None of the servlets are being compiled into the WAR. We cannot get at the build log to determine why, therefore, since WTP 2.0 requires Java 5, I've committed and released a change to HEAD only, tag v200701121858, to back out the last two changes described in comment 7 and comment 10. The contents of build-war.xml have been reverted back to those of v1.4 of the file.

I suspect the WTP 2.0 build failed since 1.4 was attempting to use, "compile against", some plugins which had been compiled with 1.5.
This was only related error msg, I could find in the logs.
/shared/webtools/build-wtp-R2.0-I/workdir/plugins/org.eclipse.wst.ws.explorer/wsexplorer/wsdl/fragment/XSDDefaultInfoFragmentJSP_jsp.java:12: cannot access org.eclipse.emf.common.util.EList bad class file: /shared/webtools/build-wtp-R2.0-I/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.emf.common_2.3.0.v200612211251.jar(org/eclipse/emf/common/util/EList.class) class file has wrong version 49.0, should be 48.0

FYI, I've changed the build back so that the default VM used, unless otherwise specified, will be at the 1.4 level. This means it will be important to specify Java 5 in the 2.0 stream, for the build-war script, at least. The technique is the same as before except the environment variable would be ${env.JAVA_5_HOME} instead of ${env.JAVA_4_HOME}. Still best to be explicit in the 1.5.x stream, just in case ... helps us not forget what's required for the special cases.

David, to clarify, I will add ${env.JAVA_5_HOME}/bin/java and ${env.JAVA_5_HOME}/bin/javac back into the JspC and javac targets in build-war.xml in HEAD only. I will leave R1_5_maintenance as-is. Let me know if I've misunderstood. Otherwise, I'll commit and release the change in time for this week's integration build.

(In reply to comment #16)
Yes, this is correct, assuming you want and expect this code to execute only with JRE 1.5. Which I think is the case ... it's only ran "within" the Development Environment, right? Not on any 'ol target environment, so 1.5 matches our requirements for WTP 2.0. (If you ever did want it to work at a "lower" JRE, you'd have to make sure all it's pre-reqs were also spec'd to run at the lower JRE.
Committed and released (tag v200701180417) this latest change to HEAD only.
Verified in 1.5.3 and 1.5.4.
Closed.

bug.short_desc: Suspending debug target does not enable resume

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061205-1200
Steps To Reproduce: In the debug view, select the debug target and suspend it. The resume action stays disabled. As soon as a selection event occurs, the actions are updated and the resume action becomes enabled.
Occurs because no selection event is sent on the suspend action. Works when suspending java threads, because the action selects the stack frame causing a selection event.
More information:

Created an attachment (id=55271) Proposed patch
Proposed patch adds SELECT flag to the IModelDelta created when suspend runs.
To me, sending the IModelDelta.SELECT request is more like a work-around. I believe this might be related to the problem that I was seeing in bug 162595.

I think this was just a bug with the debug view's context change logic. The context provider fires context change events when something is SELECTed. As well, if the state or the content of the active context changes, a context change event should be fired. However, for this case we were not firing a context change - the logic was just wrong.
The fix is to fire an ACTIVATION change when the CONTENT of the currently active context changes, or a STATE change when just the STATE of the currently active context changes.
In this particualar case we will now end up firing an activation context change as the content has changed, so a new state has really been created.
Fixed in LaunchView$ContextProvider. Please verify, Curtis.
Verified

dm

Having said all of that, it's better to have your workspace on a local drive, and use a version control system to synchronize changes -- that's how I usually work :-)

In WTP we have an action that starts a server within a Job and then opens a web browser (the platform internal browser editor in this case) when the server is ready. If the user has any open editor during that time, the file changes outside of the editor, and the editor uses an activation listener to prompt the user to reload the file, there is a recursive attempt to activate editors and the error below is written to the .log.

java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:615) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.invokeFramework(Main.java:341) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:285) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:987) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:962)

The problem seems to be that an part cannot activate another part within its own activation (as your wst.server.ui.editor editor is doing with the call to openURL on the browser support). I suggest wrapping your attempt to open the URL in a job that will run after your own editor is finished opening.

Hi Kim, Please take another look at the trace - the server editor was just an example and it is not opening up another editor. The user just happens to be clicking back into the editor after the file was modified externally. This causes the editor to open up a dialog, just like the platform Java or text editor would.
The problem is that this gives back control to the Display, which allows a background job (launched by another process) to run it's asyncExec to run and try to open it's own editor. In other words, it's already using the proposed solution.

bug.short_desc: StateObjectFactory.createState(State) does not copy platform properties

long_desc.thetext: I am trying to create a new resolver State from an existing one. After setting a resolver in the new State, it was not resolving as I expected. After getting some help, I found the platform properties were not getting copied over from the original State into my new State. Since we were not sure if the platform properties should be copied over, we decided to open a bug to get opinions.
The platform properties should be copied over just like everything else.
Fixed in HEAD.

bug.short_desc: Undo/redo action wrappers no longer maintain correct enablement

long_desc.thetext:
Changes in Eclipse Platform 3.3M4 have broken the undo/redo action wrappers in the oee.workspace.ui plug-in. These now always appear disabled in the Edit menu when an editor is (re)activated, despite the fact that the operation history can undo/redo.
The Operation History API's UndoActionHandler and RedoActionHandler that the wrappers delegate to no longer compute their enablement based solely on the history's state (there seems to be a new 'contextActive' latch).
This is found in an Integration build of EMFT Transaction 1.1 M4 with Eclipse Platform build I20061205-1200.
Committed a fix to HEAD (1.1). The same Undo/Redo action handler is now reused for a part site. A part listener removes site-to-handler mappings when parts are closed.

bug.short_desc: [Article proposal] EMF Persistance with WTP Part 2

long_desc.thetext:
EMF Persistance with WTP Part 2.
Hi I'd like to try to write an article on EMF Persistance with WTP, inspired from http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-WTP-Persisting-EMF/persisting.html
My article would describe an WTP EMF persistance on a more complex model (cocoon 2.x http://www.orcades.net/contrib/cocoon-sitemap.png ), with inheritence and some undocumented tricks. I've also write a JET template that build those EMF WTP translator from ECore file.
Sounds interesting. Can you post a few bullets defining your content, e.g. a table of contents/section list?

abstract: JET generation of "complex" wst emf translator * Introduction * EMF Model: presentation of a more "complex" model with composite(like) pattern. * Mapping Inheritance with WST Translator * Caching translator && (possibly) multi parent Element (eg: PipeplineElement ). Translator can be shared (static), but when their emf element can be contained in different parent the cache can/must be index on the reference * Building Translator with JET, as it can be a tedious task. A simple HelperModel (to navigate through EMF and help building getters ...) A Jet template.
I've sent a note to the emf-dev and wtp-dev mailing lists asking for input into this proposal.
It sounds like an interesting combination showing how to exploit various features of EMF to take advantage of some of the addtional capabilities provided by WTP.

I've also read the original article and produced a specialized editor which combines WTP's XML editor and the EMF editor (e.g. the properties and outline content models), with the models being in sync as long as the editor is open.
Is that an interesting twist? (Can't get an GMF diagram as a second tab in the XML editor due to it's reliance on EFM Transaction, but I'll deal with that later)
Also note bug 169447 and bug 164246, the former even introduces rudimentaty Junit tests for WTP2EMF.

(In reply to comment #5) > I've also read the original article and produced a specialized editor which > combines WTP's XML editor and the EMF editor (e.g. the properties and outline > content models), with the models being in sync as long as the editor is open.
So do I, as the my first goal was to build a cocoon sitemap multipage editor. It's quite functional, but I got some trouble with swt/jface behavior when refreshing property tabbed view. It use EMF command, but I'd like to switch to Operation perhaps using EMFT Transaction to implement Undo/redo.
> Is that an interesting twist? (Can't get an GMF diagram as a second tab in the > XML editor due to it's reliance on EFM Transaction, but I'll deal with that > later)
Perhaps in the same veins, I'd like to include the WST XML editor (with xml-schema based completion) in a pane of my editor, keep all of this synchronized ... but I definitively don't know where to start from the WST. Hum,
Cocoon is an important Web technology and would be of interest to WTP users. Would that article include info on how to use the editor to create a Cocoon app in WTP?

(In reply to comment #7) > Cocoon is an important Web technology and would be of interest to WTP users. > Would that article include info on how to use the editor to create a Cocoon app > in WTP? > Sure it could, I'd also like to "open" my source code to cocoon / WTP community but It's (pre)alpha status. In fact, I took the idea of an cocoon sitemap editor as a real life case to learn eclipse-plugins, EMF, WSTTranslator. I've also write an extension to the JFaceDatabinding to be EMF (notifier) aware, so changes to model are easily bound to widgets.

bug.short_desc: F3 should open definition if it can find one

long_desc.thetext:
Open definition used to be pretty slow, slower than open declaration. Also, I guess, at the time we though declarations were more important. With the new PDOM, searching for definitions is actually faster than parsing to find declarations.
I would like to change Open Declaration to use the PDOM first and then parser only if necessary, and return the definition if there is one, and if not, then the first declaration.

Wow, it works so well, I'm committing it right now. F3 is your friend, there is no need for any other. :)
It searches in the following order. 1. Definitions in AST 2. Definitions in Index 3. Declarations in AST 4. Declarations in Index
Whoops, forgot to assign it to myself.
There. woot woot.

I agree that it is a good idea to combine 'Open Declaration' and 'Open Definition' to one action.
However, with the current solution you cannot navigate from the definition (of a method) to its declaration. This is a regression that must be fixed.
Furthermore the action 'Open Definition' does not provide any extra value over 'Open Declaration' any more, as it either does the same thing, or nothing. Therefore it should be removed. Failing to do so, will confuse users.

Feel free to add to the functionality of Open Declaration, i.e. F3. It's working great as is! As I mentioned on the mailing list, you can do what ever to Open Definition as you are correct, it has little value now.
Moving off M4. I think F3 is functional enough for the milestone.

Created an attachment (id=55859) proposed patch
Doug, I have the (relatively small) change in place. The reason why I did not commit it so far is, that I wanted to put the testcases for F3 into place again, first. That turns out to be a bit more complicated than I thought. If you are ok with that, I'd like to commit the patch. I'll deliver the updated and reenabled test-cases tomorrow?
I did a quick test and it seems fine. The code looks alright too. Go ahead and commit. Thanks!
Fixed navigation from method definition to declaration, removed action 'open definition' from editor.

bug.short_desc: pde junit runtime needs to support IApplication

long_desc.thetext:
See bug 166972
It looks like more work is needed by PDE to support the new app model. The junit runtime in PDE will need to define two applications. One that supports the legacy IPlatformRunnable and one that supports the new IApplication.
The reason PDE cannot use the same application is because the legacy app must be able to run on legacy targets back to version 3.0 of Eclipse. Wassim has informed me that PDE used to have a similar situation when supporting the old 2.x platforms. It looks like a similar approach will need to be used to support 3.0, 3.1, 3.2 legacy platforms.

The new application is released and we kept the old one (and renamed it) for legacy applications.
If the target/workspace contains the equinox.app plug-in, we use the new application. Otherwise, we use the legacy one.
Changes were made in the pde.junit.runtime and the pde.ui plug-in.

12/7/06 1:00:34 PM GUI0023M: Unable to connect to the server. Please ensure that the server is up and running and that the network connection is active. If the server is down you can use the server log file to determine why the server shutdown.

GUI gave the following error when login
Error -- Server: tpc-d23-int.beaverton.ibm.com Status: 12
12/7/06 1:00:34 PM GUI0023M: Unable to connect to the server. Please ensure that the server is up and running and that the network connection is active. If the server is down you can use the server log file to determine why the server shutdown.
You probably saw the GUI produce the output above due to the Data Server not starting successfully. Can you please provide the logs from the Data Server? Earlier today, an issue in the native Linux build that prevented the Data Server from starting was identified and resolved (there was a minor error in the Aperi/data/c/T-Storm/Makefile which led to libDataServer.so library that couldn't be loaded by Java). I'm suspecting you may have encountered the same issue.
Created an attachment (id=55283) The only file in datasvr/log except AuditTrace.log

Created an attachment (id=55297) Patched libDataServer.so Linux x86-32 shared library
Thanks for posting the Data Server log file. Upon inspection, you did indeed run into the issue that was resolved earlier today. The 'adminGIDField' field is defined in Aperi/data/c/T-Storm/ServerUnix.c. The error in the attached log file occurred because the ServerUnix.o object file was not included in packaging of the libDataServer.so shared library. I've attached a patched libDataServer.so shared library. You can drop it in the 'lib' directory of your Aperi installation and move on. A new build, with the fix in place, should be available shortly.
The issue identified in this bug report has been resolved. A patch has been created for use until a new build becomes available.
Patch tested and verfified
patch tested and verified

ERROR Error - no status for RequestID 31 org.eclipse.aperi.Router update CIMOM Registrator
Steps to Reproduce: Using GUI to add/remove CIMOMs
Actual Results:
The adding CIMOM seems working OK but removing CIMOM will cause Aperi to hung
Expected Results:
Both Adding/Removing CIMOMs should work fine without errors
Build Date & Platform:
Aperi-20061206-221255 build running Windows platform

The hang condition is introduced by the class ViewReportTablesUpdater which was recently added to the project. The Derby database hangs in method handleUpdate() when executing prepared statements like the one listed at the end of this comment. Please check this statement and be aware that ViewReportTablesUpdater holds a lot more of such statements.
Is there a way to enable tracing for SQL statements that are about to be executed ?
insert into t_res_view_ssluncmp select distinct c.computer_id , ss.subsystem_id, pv.physical_volume_id , pv.serial_number , sv.svid from t_res_host c , t_res_storage_subsystem ss, t_res_storage_volume sv, t_res_physical_volume pv, t_res_dev_access da, t_res_controller ctl where lower(pv.subsystem_serial_number || '/' || pv.serial_number) = lower(sv.unique_id) and sv.subsystem_id = ss.subsystem_id and pv.physical_volume_id = da.device_id and da.controller_id = ctl.controller_id and ctl.computer_id = c.computer_id and ss.subsystem_id = ?
Note: No SQL-Exception is thrown when the statements in question are executed and the call to DBPreparedStatement.executeUpdate() never returns.

I think there are already instructions on how to add tracing to Derby. One could also set a breakpoint in ViewReportTablesUpdater to see where it hangs - I guess we need extra information at this point -- also need to check derby.log to see if there is a deadlock.

E-mail sent to aperi-dev@eclipse.org by Rodica:
I have looked at the bug and I found out that the Device Server hung because it tried to retrieve the rows of the table T_RES_STORAGE_SUBSYSTEM that had been modified (and therefore locked) as part of another transaction not yet committed.
CIMOMManager.processPendingCIMOMDeletion opens a transaction by getting a new connection: DBConnection mConn = ServiceUtils.getConnection(); and after performing some DB operations calls markDevicesAsMissing that, after performing other DB operations, performs the followings statements: ChangeDetection mChangeDetection = new ChangeDetection(pConn); mChangeDetection.complete(pConn, mTouchedEntities, pProcessID); >From the complete method the processView method of the ViewReportTablesUpdater class is called. The processView method calls in turn updateViewTables, which gets a new connection in order to update the associated view tables.
So, the ViewReportTablesUpdater.updateViewTables method creates a new connection (and therefore performs its DB operations as part of a new transaction associated with this new connection) and tries to retrieve from T_RES_STORAGE_SUBSYSTEM. On the other hand, the DB operations from CIMOMManager.processPendingCIMOMDeletion (and from other methods invoked from it), including updating the T_RES_STORAGE_SUBSYSTEM table, have been performed using another connection (and therefore as part of another transaction) which has not yet been committed when ViewReportTablesUpdater.updateViewTables method has been invoked.
There are two possible solutions depending whether the process of updating the view tables is to be performed in the same transaction as the other DB operations performed for deleting the CIMOM or in a different transaction:
1. If the update of the view tables is to be performed in the same transaction as the delete CIMOM operations we should add a new parameter to processView and updateViewTables in order to be able to transmit the connection object.
2. If the update of the view tables is to be performed in a separate transaction, we should move it after committing the delete CIMOM transaction.

My response to Rodica on mailing list:
Having traced through the code a bit myself, I believe your assessment of the problem is correct. In addition to the potential solutions you listed, we have another option. The default transaction isolation on all connections returned by DBConnPoolDataSource is TRANSACTION_READ_COMMITTED (constant integer value = 2):
A constant indicating that dirty reads are prevented; non-repeatable reads and phantom reads can occur. This level only prohibits a transaction from reading a row with uncommitted changes in it.
We can work around the issue we're facing by setting the transaction isolation on the connection returned by DBConnPoolDataSource, in ViewReportTablesUpdater.updateViewTable(), to TRANSACTION_READ_UNCOMMITTED (constant integer value = 1):
A constant indicating that dirty reads, non-repeatable reads and phantom reads can occur. This level allows a row changed by one transaction to be read by another transaction before any changes in that row have been committed (a "dirty read"). If any of the changes are rolled back, the second transaction will have retrieved an invalid row.
After adding 'connection.setTransactionIsolation(Connection.TRANSACTION_READ_UNCOMMITTED);' after 'connection = (DBConnection) ds.getPooledConnection();', the issue (which only seems to occur when attempting to remove a CIMOM against which discovery has been performed), disappeared in my workspace. Note that it isn't necessary to track and restore the isolation level of a connection, because it is automatically reset by DBConnPoolDataSource (line 113-114, in getPooledConnection()).
Now, given the nature of TRANSACTION_READ_UNCOMMITTED, and the fact that ViewReportTablesUpdater.updateViewTable() is called from multiple locations, I'm not sure that the option I've presented represents the best way to go. Hopefully, someone can take some time to perform further investigation. My sense is that updating the transaction isolation represents the easiest solution. However, if such would be problematic, either approach described in your e-mail would work fine.

Created an attachment (id=55452) Patch to resolve issue by setting connection transaction isolation.
This patch resolves the issue described in this bug report by setting the transaction isolation on the connection obtained in ViewReporTablesUpdater.updateViewTables(). The .class file should be dropped in every instance of the org.eclipse.aperi.common plugin in an installation of Aperi. If you're working from the workspace, simply import of java.sql.Connection and place the following line of code just before the for loop in updateViewTables(): 'connection.setTransactionIsolation(1);'.

If the only active transactions in that moment were the two ones, using TRANSACTION_READ_UNCOMMITTED for the second one would be a good solution, because the second transaction would read the uncommitted modifications made by the first transaction (similar, in a way, with the situation when it was a single transaction).
However, in the server might be more transactions simultaneously active, besides the mentioned two ones. Using TRANSACTION_READ_UNCOMMITTED for the second transaction would make it vulnerable (dirty reads), not only from the uncommitted modifications made by the first transaction, but also from the uncommitted modifications made by other possible transactions active at that moment.
Besides, from the "business rules" point of view, the primary DB operation (i.e. that ones from processPendingCIMOMDeletion) and the secondary DB operations (i.e. that ones from updateViewTables) should make a single big logical operation and therefore should belong to the same transaction (should be committed or rollbacked together, in order to maintain the tables content consistency). From this point of view, I would choose solution 1 (i.e. to have all the operations in one transaction). The exact implementation solution may vary: a). Add a new parameter (the connection object) to the methods b). Set the connection object (through a setConnection method) as an instance variable of the ViewReportTablesUpdater class and use it internally in the methods.
Anyway, the internal processing should be modified for ensuring a real transactional behavior: - error (SQLException) detection and processing - transaction commit/rollback and retry policy More precisely, in the inner level methods, the SQL exceptions must not be processed only locally (logged or ignored). They must be transmitted (if caught locally, must be re-thrown) to the outer level (i.e. to the level where the transaction was opened) and the whole transaction must be rollbacked and retried. Ignoring or retrying a particular operation failure from a set of operations belonging to a transaction is not a solution (might be a solution, but only in special error cases, after a precise analysis of the error code). For safeness, the recommended solution is to rollback the whole transaction and to retry it from the beginning. The commit operations must be performed once per transaction (usually in the same method which opened the transaction).

Per discussion during the 12/12 development call, I've gone ahead and checked-in the transaction isolation fix. The change should appear in the next nightly build. The patched .class file attached to this bug report can be used between now and when that build is available.
The long-term / better solution to the issue described in this bug report involves improving transaction management along the lines of Rodica's first suggestion. A new bug report will be opened to track that effort.
See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=167716 for transaction management bug report.

attachment.desc: Patch to resolve issue by setting connection transaction isolation.

bug.short_desc: ResourceException after double click on result in Search view

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 3.2.1
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create new Logic diagram 2. Select logic diagram resource in Package or Project Explorer 3. In the top level menu go to Search->Text->Worksapce 4. In the search view click on the result corresponding to your logic diagram resource file
Problem: there are exceptions logged in the errors view for a not found marker.
Expected: no exceptions logged
More information: GMF's MarkerNavigationService performs navigation to the marker as an async display message, while Eclipse's FileSearchPage expect this to run sequentially. Eclipse's FileSearchPage does the following: 1) creates marker 2) navigates to marker 3) deletes the marker
Since navigation is performed in an async message the marker is removed from the MarkersSet before navigation is performed.
There are 2 ways to fix this: 1) Navigate to marker sequentially 2) Check if the marker exists in the workspace before navigating to it. In this case navigation to the found text won't be avilable for diagram editors (which currently makes sense)

Created an attachment (id=55321) proposed patch
Regarding 2 ways to fix the issue: the patch includes both ways: 1) Doesn't seem like navigation should be done as an async display message, any longer at least (Christian Damus agrees). 2) Before navigating to marker it should always be checked for existence - this just a good practice and, hence, wouldn't hurt to have this check.
Patch has been committed. Marking as fixed

Run the snippet and notice that even though the dialog is primed with the file name "fred.bat" it shows up as fred. If you select another file type (say *.txt), it will still save it as fred.bat.
If you change the line in the snippet from:

to
